choices.text: Treponemal pallidum particle agglutination assay (TP-PA)
Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a maculopapular rash and a low-grade fever. She is 24 weeks pregnant and concerned about her unborn child. She mentions her partner was recently diagnosed with an STI. Examination reveals a widespread rash including the palms and soles, and condyloma lata. She denies any genital ulcers. What is the most appropriate initial screening test to perform in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VDRL (Veneral disease reasearch laboratory)

 

Option A:

 

VDRL is a non-treponemal serologic test commonly used for the initial screening of syphilis. It is relatively inexpensive, widely available, and provides rapid results. It is sensitive in the detection of secondary syphilis, which the patient is likely to have given her symptoms of a rash including palms and soles, condyloma lata, and a recent partner diagnosis of an STI.

 

RPR could also be given and can be marked if VDRL was not given.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The TP-PA (Treponemma pallidum particle agglutination test) is a treponemal test used for confirmation after a positive non-treponemal test rather than for initial screening.

 

Option C. The FTA-ABS (Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test) test is also a confirmatory treponemal test that remains positive for life and is not typically used for initial screening.

 

Option D. The HSV PCR test is used to diagnose herpes simplex virus infections, not syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RPR test as the appropriate initial screening tool for a pregnant woman with signs suggestive of secondary syphilis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p375, 2/e p391

questions.text: A researcher is studying the replication rate of various mycobacteria. When considering the doubling time of Mycobacterium leprae, which is responsible for leprosy, what is the typical time required for the leprae bacilli to double in number?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 days

 

Option C:

 

Mycobacterium leprae has one of the longest doubling times of any known bacteria, which is approximately 12 days. This slow replication rate contributes to the chronic nature of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium leprae has a very slow replication rate, with a doubling time of approximately 12 days, contributing to the chronic progression of leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p285, 2/e p297, Ananthanarayan 9/e p22-23, 10/e p371

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, headache, and a rash after a camping trip in an area known for scrub vegetation. He recalls multiple insect bites. A diagnosis of scrub typhus is suspected. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Doxycycline

 

Option D:

 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus, which is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is an intracellular bacterium transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythromycin: Incorrect because while it can be used in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated (such as in pregnant women or children), doxycycline is the preferred first-line treatment.

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Incorrect as it is primarily used for anaerobic bacterial infections and protozoal infections, not rickettsial diseases like scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Sulfonamides: Incorrect because they are not effective against the organism that causes scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, as it effectively targets the intracellular bacterium transmitted through chigger bites. 

Erythromycin can be an alternative in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated (e.g., pregnant women or children), but it is not the first-line choice. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p408

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient with a tick-borne illness and notes the presence of granulomas with a central necrosis surrounded by a ring of immune cells on histopathology. This finding is characteristic of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ehrlichiosis

 

Option D:

 

Doughnut granulomas, which present as granulomas with central necrosis surrounded by a ring of immune cells, are characteristic of ehrlichiosis, a tick-borne illness caused by bacteria of the genus Ehrlichia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. RMSF: Incorrect as RMSF typically presents with a vasculitic rash rather than granulomas.

 

Option B. Q fever: Incorrect because Q fever, caused by Coxiella burnetii, does not typically form doughnut granulomas.

 

Option C. Lyme disease: Incorrect as Lyme disease, caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, typically presents with erythema migrans and other systemic symptoms, not doughnut granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doughnut granulomas are the characteristic of ehrlichiosis, a tick-borne illness caused by Ehrlichia.

 

Ref:  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1875891/pdf/canmedaj01407-0016.pdf

questions.text: A public health worker is investigating a cluster of scrub typhus cases in a rural area. He is tasked with identifying the vector responsible for transmission. Which of the following is the vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chigger

 

Option B:

 

Scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers (larval mites), not by fleas, ticks, or mosquitoes. Photo showing chigger bites.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flea: Incorrect as fleas are not the vectors for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Tick: Incorrect, although ticks are common vectors for other diseases, they do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Mosquito: Incorrect as mosquitoes do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers (larval mites) and not by fleas, ticks, or mosquitoes. 

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2nd/p, Park 24/e p317 & 23/e p299

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who recently returned from a hiking trip in the mountains presents with fever and a rash. Laboratory tests show elevated Weil-Felix reaction titers, Ox 2, and Ox 19. Which organism is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickettsia rickettsii

 

Option A:

 

The Weil-Felix test, which is based on the cross-reactivity of patient serum with Proteus O antigens, can show elevated titers in various rickettsial infections. Elevated Ox 2 and Ox 19 titers are characteristic of Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, especially in a patient with outdoor exposure in mountainous areas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rickettsia prowazekii: Incorrect as it causes epidemic typhus and typically shows elevation of only Ox 19 titers, not both Ox 2 and Ox 19.

 

Option C. Rickettsia typhi: Incorrect because it causes endemic typhus and is primarily associated with Ox 19 elevation alone, typically in urban settings with rat exposure.

 

Option D. Scrub typhus: Incorrect because Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus) characteristically shows elevation of Ox K titers, not Ox 2 and Ox 19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated Ox 2 and Ox 19 titers in the Weil-Felix test are characteristic of Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, particularly in patients with recent outdoor exposure in endemic areas.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p393, 2/e p407

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of a systemic infection. His occupation involves extensive travel to rural areas. He reports no recent gastrointestinal symptoms, and his sexual history is non-contributory. Laboratory serological tests are ordered to narrow down the diagnosis. Which of the following diseases is most appropriately diagnosed serologically in this clinical context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

Option D:

 

Scrub typhus, a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is often diagnosed serologically due to the difficulty of culturing the organism. Serological tests such as the indirect immunofluorescence assay are used to detect antibodies against O. tsutsugamushi.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Typhoid: Incorrect, as typhoid fever is usually confirmed with blood cultures.

 

Option B. Q fever: Incorrect, while Q fever can be diagnosed serologically, the patient's presentation and history are more suggestive of scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Gonorrhea: Incorrect, as gonorrhea is typically diagnosed using nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) on swab specimens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhusis typically diagnosed by using serological test (immunofluorescence assay) due to the difficulty of culturing the causative organism.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p321,393,394, 2/e p406- 407

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a widespread rash that spares the palms and soles. He denies any animal exposures and has not traveled outside of an urban setting recently. The rash is accompanied by fever and headache. Which rickettsial disease could be associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidemic typhus

Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by the human body louse, presents with a characteristic rash that begins on the upper trunk around the fifth day of illness and becomes generalized, involving the entire body except for the face, palms, and soles. This pattern of rash distribution (sparing palms and soles) is a key diagnostic feature. The disease is characterized by fever, headache, and myalgia, consistent with the patient's symptoms. Urban setting without animal exposure aligns with the epidemiology of epidemic typhus.

 

The following table shows key features of rickettsial diseases that help differentiate epidemic typhus from other options:

 

Other Options:
 

B. Q fever - This is caused by Coxiella burnetii and typically presents with hepatitis, interstitial pneumonia, and fever. Q fever doesn't characteristically cause a widespread rash as described in the case.
 

C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever - While RMSF does cause a rash, it typically begins on the extremities (wrists and ankles) and involves the palms and soles. The case specifically mentions the rash spares palms and soles, which rules out RMSF.
 

D. Rickettsialpox - This rickettsial disease, caused by Rickettsia akari, presents with vesicular rashes (100% of cases) and is typically accompanied by an eschar at the site of the mite bite (90% of cases), neither of which were mentioned in this patient's presentation.
 

Educational Objective: 

Epidemic typhus presents with a characteristic rash that involves the entire body except for the face, palms, and soles, and occurs predominantly in urban settings with person-to-person transmission via body lice.

choices.text: Mild illness, for several months
Acute onset, resolving within a week

questions.text:
An infectious disease specialist is consulted for a patient who has been experiencing recurrent episodes of an illness resembling typhus. The patient initially had typhus several years ago but has had no recent exposure to lice. The episodes are characterized by fever, headache, and a rash. Laboratory tests rule out acute infections, and the patient's history and clinical presentation lead the specialist to consider a diagnosis of Brill-Zinsser disease.

 

Question: Which statement accurately describes Brill-Zinsser disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mild illness, for several months

 

Option C:

 

Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescence of epidemic typhus. This condition can occur years after the initial infection with Rickettsia prowazekii, which causes epidemic typhus. The disease typically presents as a milder illness compared to the primary infection and can persist for several months. The patient's history of previous typhus infection, coupled with the absence of recent louse exposure and the clinical presentation, aligns with Brill-Zinsser disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Latent period < 1 month - This is not characteristic of Brill-Zinsser disease, which can have a latent period of several years after the initial infection.

 

Option B. Severe form of recrudescence - Brill-Zinsser disease is usually a milder form of typhus, not a severe form.

 

Option D. Acute onset, resolving within a week - This description does not match Brill-Zinsser disease, which is characterized by a more prolonged and mild course of illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recrudescent illness (Brill-Zinsser disease)- It is a recrudescent illness occurring years after acute epidemic typhus. R. prowazekii remains latent for years; its reactivation occurs due to waning immunity, which leads to sporadic infection or outbreaks

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p405

questions.text: A medical team is investigating an outbreak of a febrile illness in a homeless shelter with poor sanitary conditions. The illness is suspected to be transmitted by lice. Which of the following diseases is transmitted by louse and should be considered in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Trench fever

 

Option C: Trench fever - Correct. 

 

Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana and is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis). It is particularly associated with poor sanitary conditions, overcrowding, and homelessness. The disease presents with recurrent fever, headache, and shin pain. It gained its name from World War I when it affected soldiers in trenches but continues to be seen in homeless populations with poor hygiene.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Endemic typhus: Incorrect, transmitted by rat fleas, not lice.

 

Option B. Scrub typhus: Incorrect, transmitted by chiggers (larval mites), not lice.

 

Option D. Q fever: Incorrect, primarily transmitted by inhalation of contaminated aerosols from infected animals, not by lice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trench fever is a louse-transmitted disease caused by Bartonella quintana that should be considered in outbreaks of febrile illness in settings with poor sanitary conditions, particularly among homeless populations.

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p315, 2/e p405-406

questions.text: A clinician is evaluating a patient with suspected rickettsial disease. The Weil-Felix test, which measures agglutinins against certain Proteus strains, is ordered. For a diagnosis of scrub typhus, which Weil-Felix reaction would be expected to show positivity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OXK

 

Option A:

 

The Weil-Felix test is a heterophile agglutination test that can be used to suggest certain rickettsial infections. A positive OXK reaction is indicative of scrub typhus caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. OXK & OX19: Incorrect, as OX19 is more associated with rickettsial diseases caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and Rickettsia typhi.

 

Option C. OX-2: Incorrect, as OX-2 is typically positive in cases of typhus due to Rickettsia typhi.

 

Option D. OX-19: Incorrect, as mentioned above, OX-19 is not primarily associated with scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p407, Ananthanarayan 9/e p408, 10/e p417- 418

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of high-grade fever, severe headache, and myalgia. He mentions that he recently assisted with the delivery of lambs in his barn. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 39.2°C (102.5°F) and has a mild cough, but no rash is appreciated. Chest radiography reveals patchy infiltrates consistent with pneumonia. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxiella burnetii

 

Option B:

 

Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q fever, a zoonotic disease that can present with flu-like symptoms, hepatitis, and atypical pneumonia. The patient's exposure to livestock, especially during parturition when the highest numbers of organisms are shed, along with his clinical presentation, is suggestive of Q fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rickettsia rickettsii is incorrect because it causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which typically presents with a characteristic rash, which the patient does not have.

 

Option C: Salmonella spp. are associated with gastrointestinal illness and not typically with pneumonia and systemic infection as described in the patient.

 

Option D: Escherichia coli is a common cause of urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal illness, not atypical pneumonia in the context of livestock exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii is a potential cause of atypical pneumonia, particularly in patients with relevant animal exposures. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p394, 2/e p409, Ananthanarayan 9/e p411, 10/e p418

questions.text: A 32-year-old male forest ranger presents with a high fever, headache, and a history of chigger exposure. On examination, he has an eschar over his right ankle and generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests are ordered to confirm rickettsial disease. Which Weil-Felix reaction result is most indicative of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High OX-K

 

Option C.

 

In scrub typhus, the Weil-Felix test typically shows high agglutination titers with the OX-K antigen. The Weil-Felix test works on the principle of antigenic cross-reactivity between rickettsial organisms and certain Proteus strains. "In scrub typhus, OX-K antibody" is elevated. This heterophile agglutination test detects antibodies that cross-react with Proteus antigens, and a titer of 1:80 or higher is considered a possible infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High OX-2: This pattern is typically seen in tick-borne spotted fever group rickettsial diseases (along with OX-19), not in scrub typhus. The patient's exposure to chiggers rather than ticks, along with the characteristic eschar, makes this pattern unlikely.

 

Option B. High OX-19: This pattern is primarily associated with epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii) and endemic typhus (Rickettsia typhi), which are transmitted by lice and fleas respectively, not chiggers. The clinical triad of eschar, regional lymphadenopathy, and maculopapular rash points to scrub typhus rather than these conditions.

 

Option D. High OX-19 and OX-2: This combined pattern is characteristic of tick-borne spotted fevers such as Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and Indian Tick Typhus caused by Rickettsia conorii. The patient's exposure to chiggers rather than ticks, and the presence of an eschar (which occurs in only about 50% of Indian Tick Typhus cases and rarely in RMSF) make this pattern inconsistent with the clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Scrub Typhus (Orientia)

 

Caused by Orienta tsutsugamushi

 

Vector Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)

 

  • ChiggerosisAmong all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans, Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis
  • Mites maintain organisms through transovarian transmission.

 

 

Clinical manifestations

 

Triad

 

  1. Eschar (at the site of bite)
  2. Regional lymphadenopathy
  3. Maculopapular rash

 

 

Treatment 

 

  • Doxycycline DOC

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastrys Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p407, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1155-59, 20/e p1306

questions.text: A 25-year-old hiker presents with a severe headache, high fever, and a petechial rash that started on the wrists and ankles and then spread to the trunk. She reports having been bitten by a tick two days before the onset of symptoms. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickettsia rickettsii

 

Option A:

 

Rickettsia rickettsii is the etiological agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which is characterized by fever, headache, and a characteristic centripetal spread of a petechial rash. The history of tick bite and the symptomatology support this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rochalimaea quintana causes trench fever, which does not typically present with a rash.

 

Option C: Rickettsia tsutsugamushi causes scrub typhus, which presents with an eschar at the site of the chigger bite, not a widespread rash.

 

Option D: Coxiella burnetii causes Q fever, which typically does not present with a rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of a tick bite followed by fever, headache, and a characteristic petechial rash spreading from the extremities to the trunk is characteristic of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p404, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1155-59, 20/e p1304

questions.text: A clinician is evaluating a patient with endocarditis and a history of exposure to farm animals. Which of the following pathogens, known for its obligate intracellular nature and chronic infection potential, is most likely responsible for this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

Option A:

 

Coxiella burnetii is an obligate intracellular pathogen that can cause chronic Q fever, which may manifest as endocarditis, particularly in patients with preexisting valve disease or immunosuppression. The history of exposure to farm animals increases the likelihood of Q fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Ehrlichia chaffeensis causes ehrlichiosis, which typically presents with flu-like symptoms and leukopenia but not chronic endocarditis.

 

Option C: Bartonella henselae is associated with cat scratch disease and can cause endocarditis, but it is not primarily associated with livestock exposure.

 

Option D: Tropheryma whipplei causes Whipple's disease, which can lead to systemic illness and endocarditis but is a rare condition and not strongly associated with animal exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii as the causative agent of chronic Q fever, which can present as endocarditis in individuals with a history of exposure to farm animals. An understanding of the pathogen's obligate intracellular nature and potential for chronic infection is key for diagnosis and management.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p392, 2/e p409, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1078,1154-9,20/e p1309

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female presents with fever and hemolytic anemia after a camping trip in the Northeastern United States. Examination of the peripheral blood smear reveals intraerythrocytic ring forms. 

 

 

Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babesia

 

Option A:

 

Babesia species are intraerythrocytic parasites transmitted by Ixodes ticks, commonly found in the Northeastern US. The presence of ring forms within red blood cells on a blood smear is characteristic of Babesiosis.

 

 

Figure: A. Thin, delicate rings of Babesia sp. in a thin blood smear. B. Babesia sp. in a thin blood smear, showing pleomorphic rings and multiplyinfected rbcs. C. Thin blood smear showing a cluster of extracellular rings. 

 

 

Figure: Babesia microti in a thin blood smear. Note the classic “Maltese Cross” tetrad-form in the infected rbc in the lower part of the image. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Ehrlichia species infect white blood cells, not erythrocytes, and typically do not present with ring forms on blood smear.

 

Option C: Spirochetes, such as those causing Lyme disease, are not visualized within red blood cells and have a distinct spiral shape.

 

Option D: Plasmodium: Although Plasmodium does infect red blood cells and produce intraerythrocytic ring forms, it is less likely than Babesia in this case due to the patient's travel history to the Northeastern United States, where babesiosis is more endemic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic intraerythrocytic ring forms of Babesia on peripheral blood smear as a diagnostic clue in patients presenting with fever and hemolytic anemia following tick exposure, especially in endemic areas. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p393, 2/e p409. 

https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/resources/pdf/benchAids/Babesia_benchaid.pdf

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a low-grade fever and a localized tender lesion on her arm. She recalls being scratched by her new kitten a week ago. On examination, you note a small papule at the scratch site and an enlarged axillary lymph node. A biopsy of the lymph node shows stellate granuloma with central necrosis surrounded by neutrophils. Which organism is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bartonella henselae

 

Option D:

 

Bartonella henselae is the causative agent of cat-scratch disease, which typically presents with localized lymphadenopathy and a history of cat scratch or bite. The biopsy findings of stellate granuloma with central necrosis are characteristic of this condition.

 

Disesaes caused by different species of Bartonella – 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis can cause granulomas with central necrosis but is not typically associated with cat scratches.

 

Option B: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which can present with lymphadenopathy but not usually with stellate granulomas.

 

Option C: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, which does not present as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The association between a history of cat scratch and the clinical presentation of lymphadenopathy with stellate granulomas on biopsy, leading to the diagnosis of cat-scratch disease caused by Bartonella henselae.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology 2/e, p86

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with advanced HIV presents with fever, weight loss, and multiple purplish nodular skin lesions. A biopsy of one lesion shows vascular proliferation with neutrophilic infiltration. Which organism is most likely causing these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bartonella henselae

 

Option D:

 

Bartonella henselae is known to cause bacillary angiomatosis, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. The condition is characterized by vascular proliferative lesions in the skin and other organs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Borrelia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease, which can include dermatological manifestations but not typically angiomatosis.

 

Option B: Bartonella quintana causes trench fever, not characterized by vascular proliferative lesions.

 

Option C: Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not present with such lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bacillary angiomatosis in an immunocompromised patient and associated vascular proliferative lesions is characteristic of Bartonella henselae infection.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1st e/p395, 2/e p411

questions.text: A patient with bacillary angiomatosis is ready to start treatment. Considering the underlying organism and its sensitivity profile, which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macrolides

 

Option A:

 

Macrolides, such as erythromycin or azithromycin, are the treatment of choice for bacillary angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae due to their efficacy in treating this infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Aminoglycosides are not the first-line treatment for Bartonella henselae infections.

 

Option C: Cephalosporins are broad-spectrum antibiotics but not first-line for this condition.

 

Option D: Carbapenems are reserved for more resistant bacterial infections and are not the first-line treatment for bacillary angiomatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrolides, particularly erythromycin or azithromycin, are the preferred treatment for bacillary angiomatosis, an infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Their effectiveness against this specific infection makes them the first-line choice. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p396, 2/e p412, Harrison’s, 20/e p1217; 19/e p1081

choices.text: Not detected by Weil-Felix reaction

questions.text: In a lecture on vector-borne diseases, a discussion on Bartonella quintana is presented. Which of the following statements about B. quintana is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tick is the vector

 

Option D:

 

Bartonella quintana is transmitted by the human body louse, not by ticks. It is the causative agent of trench fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Causes trench fever - this is correct.

 

Option B: Not detected by Weil-Felix reaction - this is correct as Weil-Felix reaction is not sensitive for Bartonella species.

 

Option C: Recurrence is common - this is correct and reflects the chronic relapsing nature of trench fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bartonella quintana is transmitted by lice and causative agent of trench fever.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p392, 2/e p411, Ananthanarayan 9/e p409, 10/e p419- 420
